Article.Abstract: Progress has recently been made in the use of synthetic peptide libraries for the identification of T cell-stimulating ligands. T cell epitopes identified from synthetic libraries are mimics of natural epitopes. Here we show how the mimicry epitopes obtained from synthetic peptide libraries enable unambiguous identification of natural T cell Ags. Synthetic peptide libraries were screened with Mycobacterium tuberculosis-reactive and -autoreactive T cell clones. In two cases, database homology searches with mimicry epitopes isolated from a dedicated synthetic peptide library allowed immediate identification of the natural antigenic protein. In two other cases, an amino acid pattern that reflected the epitope requirements of the T cell was determined by substitution and omission mixture analysis. Subsequently, the natural Ag was identified from databases using this refined pattern. This approach opens new perspectives for rapid and reliable Ag definition, representing a feasible alternative to the biochemical and genetic approaches described thus far.
Article.ArticleTitle: Definition of natural T cell antigens with mimicry epitopes obtained from dedicated synthetic peptide libraries.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Immunohematology and Blood Bank, Leiden University Medical Center, The Netherlands.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Bacterial;Immunodominant Epitopes;Peptide Library;Receptors, Antigen, T-Cell
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Antigens, Bacterial(immunology); Humans; Immunodominant Epitopes(genetics; immunology); Molecular Mimicry; Mycobacterium tuberculosis(immunology); Peptide Library; Receptors, Antigen, T-Cell(immunology); T-Lymphocytes(immunology)

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope is conserved in chaperonins from several Mycobacterium species (as leprae, bovis, tuberculosis, avium) and also other bacteria, such as Nocardia. The Swiss-prot entry corresponds to M.tuberculosis protein, a.k.a 60 kDa chaperonin 2, Protein Cpn60-2, groEL protein 2, 65 kDa antigen, Cell wall protein A, Antigen A.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described epitope-specific T cell clone (named here MT1, but known also as Rp151-1) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. A mimotope described in this reference is also stimulating, albeit to a lower degree.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope is conserved in both Mycobacterium tuberculosis and M. bovis, and in the 85B and 85A antigens. The Swiss-prot entry corresponds to M.tuberculosis protein, a.k.a Extracellular alpha-antigen, Antigen 85 complex B, Ag85B, Mycolyl transferase 85B, Fibronectin-binding protein B, 30 kDa extracellular protein.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described epitope-specific T cell clone (named here MT2, but known also as CAAp151-3) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. A mimotope described in this reference is also stimulating, albeit to a lower degree.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope is conserved in other mammals (such as mouse, rat and pig) glutamate decarboxilase 2 proteins. The Swiss-prot entry corresponds to human protein, a.k.a Glutamate decarboxylase 2; Glutamate decarboxylase, 65 kDa isoform; GAD-65; 65 kDa glutamic acid decarboxylase.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone is not described.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described epitope-specific T cell clone (named here HG, but known also as PM1#11) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. Two mimotopes described in this reference are also stimulating.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is a mimotope of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope was from a 14-mer peptide library as the one stimulating a T cell clone specific for peptide AKTIAYDEEARRGL (aas 2-15 of HSP65 protein from mycobacteria). Subsequent search for homologue peptides in the M. tuberculosis SHOTGUN database retrieves the natural epitope as hit number 8, validating the experimental results.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described HSP65 (2-15)-specific T cell clone (named here MT1, but known also as Rp151-1) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. The mimicked natural epitope described is also stimulating, to an even higher degree.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is a mimotope of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope was from a 14-mer peptide library as the one stimulating a T cell clone specific for peptide SPSMGRDIKVQFQS (aas 55-68 of 85B Ag from M. tuberculosis). Subsequent search for homologue peptides in the M. tuberculosis SHOTGUN database failed to retrieve the natural epitope as a hit. As a result, an omission and substitution analysis for the artificial peptide was performed to analyze the aminoacid requirement for stimulation of the clone, as a way to validate the mimicry found. With those results, a new search was performed and the natural epitope was retrieved as hit number 9, validating the experimental results and suggesting that similarity rather than homology between mimotopes and natural epitopes is required for natural Ag identification.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described 85B(55-68)-specific T cell clone (named here MT2, but known also as CAAp151-3) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. The mimicked natural epitope is also stimulating, even to a higher degree. Subsequent analysis of key residues involved in T cell recognition yielded the following pattern: position 4 (P4) = (L,I,M,V,A,G,W,Y,F); P5= G; P6, (I,L,R,S,T,N,D,W,Y); P7=(D,N,S,T); P8= I; P9=(P,K,R,H); P10=(V,T,I,K).

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is a mimotope of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope was from a 14-mer peptide library as the one stimulating a T cell clone specific for peptide TVYGAFDPLLAVAD (aas 339-352 of human GAD65). Subsequent search for homologue peptides in a human abstract of Swiss-prot database failed to retrieve the natural epitope as a hit. As a result, an omission and substitution analysis for the artificial peptide was performed to analyze the aminoacid requirement for stimulation of the clone, as a way to validate the mimicry found. With those results, a new search was performed and the natural epitope was retrieved, validating the experimental results and suggesting that similarity rather than homology between mimotopes and natural epitopes is required for natural Ag identification.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone is not described.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described GAD65 (339-352)-specific T cell clone (named here HG, but known also as PM1#11) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner. The mimicked natural epitope is also stimulating, even to a higher degree.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is a mimotope of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This epitope was from a 14-mer peptide library as the one stimulating a T cell clone specific for peptide TVYGAFDPLLAVAD (aas 339-352 of human GAD65). Subsequent search for homologue peptides in a human abstract of Swiss-prot database retrieves the natural epitope as hit number 30, validating the experimental results.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone is not described.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described GAD65 (339-352)-specific T cell clone (named here hg, but known also as PM1#11) is shown to proliferate in the presence of peptide in a dose-response manner, even more effectively than the mimicked natural epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide arose from a Mycobacterium tuberculosis SHOTGUN database search for peptides containing a set of aminoacid requirements for stimulation of a T cell clone, defined as a way to validate the mimicry found between the original epitope of that clone (SPSMGRDIKVQFQS) and the mimotope recovered from a phage display 14-mer library (NSAIGIDIPVARRD). By that set of requirements(position 4 (P4) = (L,I,M,V,A,G,W,Y,F); P5= G; P6, (I,L,R,S,T,N,D,W,Y); P7=(D,N,S,T); P8= I; P9=(P,K,R,H); P10=(V,T,I,K)), this peptide sequence was retrieved, and subsequently stated to be recognized by the T cell clone, validating the requirement definition and suggesting that similarity rather than homology is required for Ag recognition.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described SPSMGRDIKVQFQS-specific T cell clone (named here MT2, but known also as CAAp151-3) is stated to proliferate in the presence of this peptide.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide arose from a Mycobacterium tuberculosis SHOTGUN database search for peptides containing a set of aminoacid requirements for stimulation of a T cell clone, defined as a way to validate the mimicry found between the original epitope of that clone (SPSMGRDIKVQFQS) and the mimotope recovered from a phage display 14-mer library (NSAIGIDIPVARRD). By that set of requirements(position 4 (P4) = (L,I,M,V,A,G,W,Y,F); P5= G; P6, (I,L,R,S,T,N,D,W,Y); P7=(D,N,S,T); P8= I; P9=(P,K,R,H); P10=(V,T,I,K)), this peptide sequence was retrieved, and subsequently stated to be recognized by the T cell clone, validating the requirement definition and suggesting that similarity rather than homology is required for Ag recognition.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Origin of this CD4+ T cell clone was described in a previous reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Previously described SPSMGRDIKVQFQS-specific T cell clone (named here MT2, but known also as CAAp151-3) is stated to proliferate in the presence of this peptide.
